Well, in my view, the the greatest
challenge relating to human rights today
is poverty. Now the reason I I choose to
uh you know say that is that poverty is
one of those issues which is uh which is
in direct denial of all the human rights
which one wants to protect be it the
civil and political rights or the
economic, social and cultural rights.
And unfortunately
people for many years we have neglected
this area of human rights law where our
emphasis was far too much on civil and
political rights and rather in some ways
ignoring the importance of economic,
social and cultural rights. And of
course the second aspect of poverty is
that it's one of disempowerment of
people. So if if people are in some ways
poor and are not able to uh in fact
fulfill their basic needs they obviously
are not in a position to exercise in
full respect the benefits of other human
rights. So to in my view poverty is one
of the greatest challenge of human
rights. Of course we do have um today in
more recent times we have seen the
problem of terrorism and how it affects
the human rights of people. In fact uh
ironically terrorism is a one of the
greatest challenge of human rights but
also our responses to ter terrorism can
also violate human rights in causing
discrimination or other forms of biases
against human rights and including
undermining of civil liberties. In fact,
a number of countries all over all over
the world including US have in response
to 9/11 in the US but also other
terrorist acts in other countries
including India. My country for example
there have been laws that have been
passed uh to sort of fight terrorism but
many of these laws are in many ways
undermining the human rights and civil
liberties which have which which took
many years for the international
community to evolve. So that's uh in my
view the sort of second serious uh
challenge relating to human rights. And
the third one I would increasingly uh
recognize in the developing countries is
corruption. Now this is an area which
again very little work has been done. My
own research work has focused on the
implications of corruption for human
rights. In fact, I would uh argue that
uh corruption as it is prevalent in a
large number of developing countries uh
in the developing world so to say has
direct implication for human rights. Be
it civil and political rights whereby
torture is committed against people who
are not in a position to pay bribe or
they are in some ways engaging with the
criminal justice system or law
enforcement machinery or for that matter
your uh development funds the money that
is allocated for say poverty elevation
programs or money that is allocated for
building hospitals or schools this this
money is swindled by the politicians or
bureaucrats. This in some ways uh in in
many ways directly affects the
enforcement of economic, social and
culture rights. More recently the
earthquakes in China has also
demonstrated how corruption in
construction industry has even resulted
in uh people losing lives because these
buildings were not properly built. So
this is a an area which is an evolving
area and increasingly it is important
for us to recognize that corruption is
not only just a law enforcement issue
where a particular law is violated and a
few people are becoming richer but there
is also a huge uh enfor rule of law
issue which affects the fundamental
fabric of any society and that's why I
would look at corruption to be one of
the very serious human rights issues. Of
course we still have issues relating to
discrimination of all kind. In my
country there continues to be
discrimination against people belonging
to lower class people. Uh women are also
put under disadvantage in many
societies. Uh this is an area we have to
work on. In the US obviously there are
issues relating to discrim uh racial
discrimination and in some other
countries there are issues relating to
how human rights defenders are
constantly under threat. So these are
some of the broad human rights
challenges for the for the future.
